summary: This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher J. Dilorio to various SEC officials and judges, primarily dated from 2020-2021. It details his allegations of widespread SEC corruption, obstruction, and failure to investigate his claims related to market manipulation, accounting fraud, and money laundering involving entities like Knight Capital (NITE), Eastman Kodak (KODK), and various individuals connected to Blackstone, Trump, and Kushner networks. He appeals a preliminary denial of his whistleblower award and provides extensive supporting allegations.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: The author of the emails, alleging massive SEC corruption, obstruction of his whistleblower claims, and detailed knowledge of frauds involving Knight Capital, Kodak, and other entities.

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: Former SEC Chairman accused by Dilorio of corruption, non-disclosure of conflicts, and obstructing investigations into entities like NITE and Kodak.

persons.name: Steve Schwarzman
persons.context: Described as being on the SEC's 'do not investigate list,' involved in the Knight Capital bailout and the Kodak (KODK) fraud.

persons.name: Jared Kushner
persons.context: Mentioned in connection to his college roommate running the DFC, which loaned to Kodak, and linked to historical business dealings in Sedona/Scan Graphics.

persons.name: George Karfunkel
persons.context: Founder of American Stock Transfer, donor to Congregation Chemdas Yisroel, involved in Eastman Kodak stock and linked to Moses Marx.

persons.name: Moses Marx
persons.context: Business associate of George Karfunkel, involved in Berkshire Bancorp and Eastman Kodak stock dealings.

persons.name: Barry Honig
persons.context: Involved in GRQ Consultants and money laundering shells like Cell Power Technologies, linked to Jaclin and other schemes.

persons.name: Jason New
persons.context: Blackstone executive on Kodak board, involved in the internal investigation of Kodak and linked to Blink Charging.

persons.name: Michael Farkas
persons.context: CEO of Blink Charging (BLNK), described as a 'prolific Bag Man,' linked to money laundering shells SkyWay and i Incubator.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.context: Bag man associated with JMJ, barred by FINRA but allegedly still active in schemes like Blink Charging, detailed in Dilorio's TCR.

persons.name: Joshie Sason
persons.context: Bag man involved with Hanover/Magna, NewLead, FreeSeas, implicated in SEC complaints based on Dilorio's information.

persons.name: Douglas Cifu
persons.context: CEO of Virtu Financial (VIRT), which owns NITE. Accused of running a criminal enterprise and having a corrupt relationship with SEC attorney Lara Shalov Mehraban.

persons.name: Lara Shalov Mehraban
persons.context: SECNY attorney accused by Dilorio of criminal obstruction and having a corrupt relationship with her former Paul Weiss colleague, Douglas Cifu.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Former colleague of Jay Clayton at Sullivan & Cromwell, accused of playing a key role in the fraud keeping NITE operational.

persons.name: Dick Best
persons.context: New Director of SECNY, formerly at FINRA where he brought a BBH AML complaint. Accused by Dilorio of criminally obstructing investigation into his claims.

persons.name: Judge Swain
persons.context: Recipient of Dilorio's email, referenced in context of her past Sedona/Refco decision and the assertion that 'absolutely nothing has changed.'

persons.name: Judge Cave
persons.context: Recipient of Dilorio's email, urged to treat SEC evidence with skepticism and consider a stay in the Kamensky case.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Recipient of Dilorio's email, urged to treat SEC evidence with skepticism and consider a stay in the Kamensky case.

persons.name: David Urban
persons.context: Trump PA campaign manager on the board of NITE and FSD Pharma (HUGE), involved in SEC-facilitated pump and dump schemes.

persons.name: Janey
persons.context: Frequent recipient of Dilorio's emails, referenced as 'the record Janey,' an SEC official involved in handling his whistleblower claims.

persons.name: Hoecker
persons.context: Frequent recipient of Dilorio's emails, an SEC official accused of being part of the corruption and obstruction.

persons.name: Oleg Firer
persons.context: Described as a 'prolific Bag Man,' linked to Acies Corp, Allied Wallet, WireCard, and Jaclin-related money laundering shells.

persons.name: Bill Richardson
persons.context: Linked to Blink Charging and Jeff Epstein's New Mexico Zorro Ranch.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as a business partner of Andrew/Jonathan Farkas and connected to Steve Schwarzman and Bill Richardson.

connections.description: Dilorio accuses Clayton of corruption, non-disclosure of conflicts, and leading the SEC's obstruction of his whistleblower claims.
Linked through political and business networks, with Schwarzman described as connected to Kushner and Epstein.
Longtime business partners involved together in United Equities/Commodities, Berkshire Bancorp, and Eastman Kodak stock.
Both involved in money laundering shell companies; Honig's GRQ was involved in Cell Power, and Farkas is linked to Blink Charging.
Jason New is a Blackstone executive, placing him in a direct reporting relationship to Schwarzman.
Alleged corrupt relationship where Mehraban, a former colleague of Cifu at Paul Weiss, is accused of obstructing investigations into his company, Virtu/NITE.
Former colleagues at Sullivan & Cromwell; Fishman is accused of playing a key role in the fraud keeping NITE operational.
Both described as 'Bag Men' involved in money laundering shell schemes and convertible note fraud, detailed in Dilorio's TCR.
Urban was Trump's PA campaign manager and is on the board of NITE, linking political and financial networks.
Farkas's relative Andrew/Jonathan Farkas is described as a business partner of Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Knight Capital Trading Glitch and Bailout
events.description: A software glitch caused Knight Capital's stock to collapse from over $10 to nearly $2.50, leading to a bailout by a consortium including Blackstone, Goldman Sachs, and Jefferies.

events.title: Phlow Corporation Awarded $354M Government Contract
events.description: Phlow Corp, linked to Kodak's DFC loan application, received a $354 million HHS contract to manufacture hydroxychloroquine and other medicines.

events.title: SEC Approves Blink Charging Public Offering
events.description: The SEC approved a public offering for Blink Charging (BLNK) despite Dilorio's allegations it was a money laundering shell, facilitating a pump and dump.

events.title: Blink Charging PR Drives Stock Surge
events.description: Blink Charging issued a press release about a grant for charging stations, driving the stock up 27% without filing a required 8-K, alleged to be a fraudulent pump.

events.title: Dilorio's Formal Appeal of Whistleblower Denial
events.description: Christopher Dilorio formally appealed the SEC's preliminary denial of his Opco whistleblower award, alleging a five-year delay and corrupt obstruction.

events.title: SEC Adopts 'Christopher J. Dilorio Rule'
events.description: The SEC adopted a new whistleblower rule (240.21F-18) allowing denial of awards if staff never saw the information, which Dilorio claims was created to deny him compensation.

locations: 1428 36th Street, Suite 200, Brooklyn, NY 11218 (Address for Congregation Chemdas Yisroel, Roth CPA, and historical shell company Cell Power Technologies)
Zorro Ranch, New Mexico (Jeff Epstein's property linked to Bill Richardson)
Washington (Mentioned as purported site of Mullen EV production, alleged to be fraudulent)
keyFacts: The whistleblower, Christopher J. Dilorio, alleges the SEC is a criminal organization that actively obstructs investigations, protects entities like Knight Capital/NITE and individuals like Steve Schwarzman, and facilitates massive frauds on the public.

Dilorio claims a $765 million DFC loan to Eastman Kodak (KODK) was a fraud involving Jared Kushner's college roommate, Steve Schwarzman's Blackstone, and insider trading by George Karfunkel and Moses Marx, with no SEC investigation.
The document alleges a deep, corrupt relationship between SEC officials (e.g., Lara Shalov Mehraban) and the entities they are supposed to regulate (e.g., Virtu Financial's Douglas Cifu).

Dilorio asserts that the core business of Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu (NITE) is and always has been abusive naked shorting of OTC markets to facilitate money laundering, and the SEC enables this through mechanisms like the DTCC's Obligation Warehouse.

The SEC is accused of creating a specific whistleblower rule (240.21F-18) to deny Dilorio an award, which he dubs the 'Christopher J. Dilorio Rule,' as part of a pattern of running out the clock on his claims.
